trans-unit.source: Create and Configure an Application Gateway with Internal Load Balancer (ILB) using Azure Resource Manager | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and Configure an Application Gateway with Internal Load Balancer (ILB) using Azure Resource Manager | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This page provides instructions to create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway with Internal Load balancer (ILB) for Azure resource manager
trans-unit.target: This page provides instructions to create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway with Internal Load balancer (ILB) for Azure resource manager

trans-unit.source: Application Gateway can be configured with an internet facing VIP or with an internal end-point not exposed to the internet, also known as Internal Load Balancer (ILB) endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Application Gateway can be configured with an internet facing VIP or with an internal end-point not exposed to the internet, also known as Internal Load Balancer (ILB) endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the gateway with an ILB is useful for internal line of business applications not exposed to internet.
trans-unit.target: Configuring the gateway with an ILB is useful for internal line of business applications not exposed to internet.

trans-unit.source: It's also useful for services/tiers within a multi-tier application which sit in a security boundary not exposed to internet, but still require round robin load distribution, session stickiness, or SSL termination.
trans-unit.target: It's also useful for services/tiers within a multi-tier application which sit in a security boundary not exposed to internet, but still require round robin load distribution, session stickiness, or SSL termination.

trans-unit.source: This article will walk you through the steps to configure an application gateway with an ILB.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk you through the steps to configure an application gateway with an ILB.

trans-unit.source: Install latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: Install latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.

trans-unit.source: You will create a virtual network and subnet for Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: You will create a virtual network and subnet for Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Make sure no Virtual machines or cloud deployments are using the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Make sure no Virtual machines or cloud deployments are using the subnet.

trans-unit.source: Application gateway must be by itself in a virtual network subnet.
trans-unit.target: Application gateway must be by itself in a virtual network subnet.

trans-unit.source: The servers which you will configure to use the Application gateway must exist or have their endpoints created either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.
trans-unit.target: The servers which you will configure to use the Application gateway must exist or have their endpoints created either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.

trans-unit.source: Back end server pool: The list of IP addresses of the back end servers.
trans-unit.target: Back end server pool: The list of IP addresses of the back end servers.

trans-unit.source: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the virtual network subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.
trans-unit.target: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the virtual network subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.

trans-unit.source: Back end server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie based affinity.
trans-unit.target: Back end server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie based affinity.

trans-unit.source: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.
trans-unit.target: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.

trans-unit.source: Front end Port: This port is the public port opened on the application gateway.
trans-unit.target: Front end Port: This port is the public port opened on the application gateway.

trans-unit.source: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the back end servers.
trans-unit.target: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the back end servers.

trans-unit.source: Listener: The listener has a frontend port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).
trans-unit.target: Listener: The listener has a frontend port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).

trans-unit.source: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the back end server pool and defines which back end server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.
trans-unit.target: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the back end server pool and defines which back end server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.

trans-unit.source: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.
trans-unit.target: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.

trans-unit.source: The difference between using Azure Classic and Azure Resource Manager will be the order you will create the application gateway and items needed to be configured.
trans-unit.target: The difference between using Azure Classic and Azure Resource Manager will be the order you will create the application gateway and items needed to be configured.

trans-unit.source: With Resource manager, all items which will make an Application Gateway will be configured individually and then put together to create the Application Gateway resource.
trans-unit.target: With Resource manager, all items which will make an Application Gateway will be configured individually and then put together to create the Application Gateway resource.

trans-unit.source: Here follows the steps needed to create an Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: Here follows the steps needed to create an Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Create a resource group for Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Create a resource group for Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Create virtual network, subnet for Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create virtual network, subnet for Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: Create an Application Gateway configuration object
trans-unit.target: Create an Application Gateway configuration object

trans-unit.source: Create Application Gateway resource
trans-unit.target: Create Application Gateway resource

trans-unit.source: Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: More info is available at Using <linkText>Windows Powershell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More info is available at Using <linkText>Windows Powershell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.
trans-unit.target: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.

trans-unit.source: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.
trans-unit.target: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.

trans-unit.source: Make sure all commands to create an Application Gateway will use the same resource group.
trans-unit.target: Make sure all commands to create an Application Gateway will use the same resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the example above we created a resource group called "appgw-rg" and location "West US".
trans-unit.target: In the example above we created a resource group called "appgw-rg" and location "West US".

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a virtual network using Resource manager:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a virtual network using Resource manager:

trans-unit.source: Assigns the Address range 10.0.0.0/24 to subnet variable to be used to create a virtual network
trans-unit.target: Assigns the Address range 10.0.0.0/24 to subnet variable to be used to create a virtual network

trans-unit.source: Creates a virtual network named "appgwvnet" in resource group "appw-rg" for the West US region using the prefix 10.0.0.0/16 with subnet 10.0.0.0/24
trans-unit.target: Creates a virtual network named "appgwvnet" in resource group "appw-rg" for the West US region using the prefix 10.0.0.0/16 with subnet 10.0.0.0/24

trans-unit.source: Creates a Application Gateway IP configuration named "gatewayIP01".
trans-unit.target: Creates a Application Gateway IP configuration named "gatewayIP01".

trans-unit.source: When Application Gateway starts, it will pick up an IP address from the subnet configured and route network traffic to the IP addresses in the backend IP pool.
trans-unit.target: When Application Gateway starts, it will pick up an IP address from the subnet configured and route network traffic to the IP addresses in the backend IP pool.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind each instance will take one IP address.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind each instance will take one IP address.

trans-unit.source: This step will configure the back end IP address pool named "pool01" with IP addresses "10.0.0.10,10.0.0.11, 10.0.0.12".
trans-unit.target: This step will configure the back end IP address pool named "pool01" with IP addresses "10.0.0.10,10.0.0.11, 10.0.0.12".

trans-unit.source: Those will be the IP addresses receiving the network traffic coming from the front end IP endpoint.You will replace the IP addresses above to add your own application IP address endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Those will be the IP addresses receiving the network traffic coming from the front end IP endpoint.You will replace the IP addresses above to add your own application IP address endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Configures Application Gateway settings "poolsetting01" for the load balanced network traffic in the backend pool.
trans-unit.target: Configures Application Gateway settings "poolsetting01" for the load balanced network traffic in the backend pool.

trans-unit.source: Configures the front end IP port named "frontendport01" for the ILB.
trans-unit.target: Configures the front end IP port named "frontendport01" for the ILB.

trans-unit.source: Creates the front end IP configuration called "fipconfig01" and associates with a private IP from the current virtual network subnet.
trans-unit.target: Creates the front end IP configuration called "fipconfig01" and associates with a private IP from the current virtual network subnet.

trans-unit.source: Creates the listener called "listener01" and associates the front end port to the frontend IP configuration.
trans-unit.target: Creates the listener called "listener01" and associates the front end port to the frontend IP configuration.

trans-unit.source: Creates the load balancer routing rule called "rule01", configuring the load balancer behavior.
trans-unit.target: Creates the load balancer routing rule called "rule01", configuring the load balancer behavior.

trans-unit.source: Configures the instance size of the Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Configures the instance size of the Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.
trans-unit.target: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.

trans-unit.source: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.
trans-unit.target: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.

trans-unit.source: You can choose between StandardSmall, StandardMedium and Standard_Large.
trans-unit.target: You can choose between StandardSmall, StandardMedium and Standard_Large.

trans-unit.source: Creates an Application Gateway will all configuration items from the steps above.
trans-unit.target: Creates an Application Gateway will all configuration items from the steps above.

trans-unit.source: In the example the Application Gateway is called "appgwtest".
trans-unit.target: In the example the Application Gateway is called "appgwtest".

trans-unit.source: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Billing for an application gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing for an application gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.

trans-unit.source: Note: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: Note: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: For the example below, the Application Gateway is called "appgwtest" and the resource group is "appgw-rg":
trans-unit.target: For the example below, the Application Gateway is called "appgwtest" and the resource group is "appgw-rg":

trans-unit.source: Get the Application Gateway object and associate to a variable "$getgw":
trans-unit.target: Get the Application Gateway object and associate to a variable "$getgw":

trans-unit.source: Use Start-AzureApplicationGateway to start the Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: Use Start-AzureApplicationGateway to start the Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of gateway.

trans-unit.source: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.
trans-unit.target: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.

trans-unit.source: This sample shows an application gateway that is up, running, and is ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: This sample shows an application gateway that is up, running, and is ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: To delete an application gateway, you'll need to do the following in order:
trans-unit.target: To delete an application gateway, you'll need to do the following in order:

trans-unit.source: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This sample shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.
trans-unit.target: This sample shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.

trans-unit.source: Get the Application Gateway object and associate to a variable "$getgw":
trans-unit.target: Get the Application Gateway object and associate to a variable "$getgw":

trans-unit.source: Use Stop-AzureApplicationGateway to stop the Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: Use Stop-AzureApplicationGateway to stop the Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Once the application gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.
trans-unit.target: Once the application gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.

trans-unit.source: The "-force" switch can be used to suppress the remove confirmation message
trans-unit.target: The "-force" switch can be used to suppress the remove confirmation message

trans-unit.source: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This step is not required.
trans-unit.target: This step is not required.

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure an application gateway to use with ILB, see <linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure an application gateway to use with ILB, see <linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:
trans-unit.target: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Traffic Manager</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Traffic Manager</linkText><title></title>
